issuetype.description: An improvement or enhancement to an existing feature or task.
issuetype.name: Improvement

resolution.description: Signifies completion of tasks, info requests, etc.
resolution.name: Completed

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.description: *Assessment* If a cloud user is one of the following: * a user who has been synced through LDAP/AD (automatically has a login profile) or * a user has been created through euare commands, and has a login profile but doesn't have an IAM policy to allow DescribeAvailabilityZones, the error message from the Management Console states the following: {quote} Your session has timed out. This may be due to inactivity, a policy that does not provide login permissions, or an unexpected error. Please log in again, and contact your cloud administrator if the problem persists. {quote} Given that the error in the log file on the Management Console machine states the following: {code} AWSAccessKeyId=AKI6BW2LMKJOI0YPKXX0&Action=DescribeAvailabilityZones&SecurityToken=ZXVjYQAB21sWyNeWrLmpOMADaz0PsUEmFJ6s5nZB1ehRlfa23Vk70OM%2B3eMWUiKkfNMM9TqDiBZjB%2FRUfTU9zkyAF18dwcUxJ0kCQEJrfUYYpA%2Fxl%2B3T2O38grlruceplUz%2FSA09GnT2m1melXqQ6SIef8PX7ZPFuQqCnEqPxQDKNcx26AEbZ3pk6Xo8SCbBG5AIxVxPWiUnAWydlYoDW0dEEE%2BuQNfZKdX6V1J9HIZOCOocHC1q54r98egvvaE%3D&SignatureMethod=HmacSHA256&SignatureVersion=2&Timestamp=2014-10-06T21%3A30%3A42Z&Version=2012-12-01 2014-10-06 14:30:42 DEBUG len(b64)=44 2014-10-06 14:30:42 DEBUG base64 encoded digest: AJoJz8B/vPCLGl1hJdWHT9qZJ1eCStZfE1YlPKWSDQs= 2014-10-06 14:30:42 DEBUG query_string: AWSAccessKeyId=AKI6BW2LMKJOI0YPKXX0&Action=DescribeAvailabilityZones&SecurityToken=ZXVjYQAB21sWyNeWrLmpOMADaz0PsUEmFJ6s5nZB1ehRlfa23Vk70OM%2B3eMWUiKkfNMM9TqDiBZjB%2FRUfTU9zkyAF18dwcUxJ0kCQEJrfUYYpA%2Fxl%2B3T2O38grlruceplUz%2FSA09GnT2m1melXqQ6SIef8PX7ZPFuQqCnEqPxQDKNcx26AEbZ3pk6Xo8SCbBG5AIxVxPWiUnAWydlYoDW0dEEE%2BuQNfZKdX6V1J9HIZOCOocHC1q54r98egvvaE%3D&SignatureMethod=HmacSHA256&SignatureVersion=2&Timestamp=2014-10-06T21%3A30%3A42Z&Version=2012-12-01 Signature: AJoJz8B/vPCLGl1hJdWHT9qZJ1eCStZfE1YlPKWSDQs= 2014-10-06 14:30:42 DEBUG Final headers: {'Content-Length': '512', 'Content-Type': 'application/x-www-form-urlencoded; charset=UTF-8', 'Host': '10.104.1.186', 'User-Agent': 'Boto/2.32.1 Python/2.6.6 Linux/2.6.32-431.29.2.el6.x86_64'} 2014-10-06 14:30:42 DEBUG Response headers: [('content-length', '223'), ('content-type', 'application/xml; charset=UTF-8')] 2014-10-06 14:30:42 DEBUG UnauthorizedOperationYou are not authorized to perform this operation.a0514c8a-0252-4e5b-a3e6-db177aec1d21 2014-10-06 14:30:42 ERROR 403 UnauthorizedOperation 2014-10-06 14:30:42 ERROR UnauthorizedOperationYou are not authorized to perform this operation.a0514c8a-0252-4e5b-a3e6-db177aec1d21 2014-10-06 14:30:42 ERROR account2/user13 [OqYAlbZfkoXYDMnO]: You are not authorized to perform this operation. {code} I think the error message in the screen could be a bit more accurate. *Steps* # Set up a Eucalyptus 4.0.1 cloud with Eucalyptus DNS enabled # Set up Eucalyptus Management Console # Add an account, user, and group via euare commands # Add user login profile to the user # Attempt to log into the Management Console with that user and observe the message in the browser. Confirm the error message above in the Management Console log file.
fields.summary: Error for Unauthorized Cloud User Can Be More Accurate
fields.environment:
* non-HA, Eucalyptus DNS enabled, Load Balancer enabled
* 1 x Management Console
* 1 x CLC, Cloudformation, UFS, Eucalyptus DNS
* 1 x UFS
* 1 x UFS, Walrus
* 1 x CC (Managed), SC (DAS0
* 1 x NC

comments.body: We document that you must add at least a minimal access policy for IAM users. We could do a better job of differentiating between 403 Timeout error vs a 403 Unauthrorized error. I think we already have a ticket open for that.
Investigating, I think we need a common error handling function in javascript. That's where we need to check for "Not authorized" in the response and notify, but not show the timed out dialog.
https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucaconsole/pull/1047
I just moved into review, but merged the branch since you'd already looked it over and tests passed.
Pull request 1047 merged
This was not fixed.  Created a user called testuser2 as described in the bug.  I tried to login as the user and received the original error message as described in the bug.
I also tried other limited permissions on users and got the same error message when trying to access denied areas.

The fix in this PR was to ensure we had consistent error handling and messaging. [~jloza], if we could accurately determine if the 403 came from a permissions issue vs a session timeout, what messaging would you like? Currently, there's a combined error message:
"Your session has timed out. This may be due to inactivity, a policy that does not provide login permissions, or an unexpected error. Please log in again, and contact your cloud administrator if the problem persists."

"You do not have the required permissions to perform this operation. Please retry the operation, and contact your cloud administrator to request an updated access policy if the problem persists."

^^ This assumes you don't have to kick the user back to the login page when this happens, and can display this error on the page they were on. Thanks, [~dkavanagh]!
https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucaconsole/pull/1179
PR 1179 merged

[~dkavanagh], [~jloza]: I assigned a user with Read-Only access and most of the areas where this user doesn't have access to, gets redirected to the logon screen with the original error message.  The only one I saw that has the new message was when I tried to create buckets.  I'm wondering if it would be better to just remove these options if a user does not have access.  For instance, if a user has read only access, then he should not even see buttons to launch instances, create volumes, snapshots, etc (or these buttons should be disabled).  I know it is probably harder to do this but it would be a much better UX if it were done that way.

[~ccassler], agreed, we would love to have that UX, but because there's no API to roll up the policies and present that info, we'd have to parse all the policies and figure it out ourselves, which is an insane amount of effort. 

At this point we can't do that, no matter how much we'd like to. 

[~dkavanagh], can we give the new error message in all cases where ops are denied due to access restrictions? I was expecting that the PR would do that, maybe it just addressed one spot.
[~dkavanagh], did you have any thoughts to what [~jloza] was suggesting?
The PR started showing the prescribed message if the response from the CLC has "Access Denied" in the message. As best I can tell, that's the only indication we get about an access restriction.

[~dkavanagh], [~jloza]:  Honestly, I would like to leave this open until a better messaging system exists for unauthorized users.  The error messages for improper access do not make sense and are a bit misleading to the user.  I would prefer a better system for this.
the pr for GUI-1589 should address this as well: https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucaconsole/pull/1272
PR 1272 merged
[~dkavanagh]: I just tried to launch an instance with a 'Monitor Only' user and I got the Session Timeout error message as described in the bug.
Please, re-open if not actually fixed.

[~ccassler] to reproduce this and look at the message we're getting back, I'd like to know more about the environment. What version is the back end? What policy did you use (exactly)? Or, if you could point me to a test setup, I'll use that.
In each case previously, I've  had to look at the code and message that comes back to determine if this result indicates a permission issue vs expired creds. I'll have to see if we have a new scenario here that gives me something different. This is the code that makes that determination: https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucaconsole/blob/master/eucaconsole/views/__init__.py#L359-L372

[~dkavanagh]:
I still see this happening in my environment.  Please look at https://console-lb-000290555290.lb.g-26-04.autoqa.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com using ui-test-acct-00.  Here's a scenario I tried.
# Gave user Monitor Only access
# Logged in as that user
# I attempted to launch an instance using the wizard
# I am then presented with the login screen and receive this error message:
{code}
Your session has timed out. This may be due to inactivity, a policy that does not provide login permissions, or an unexpected error. Please log in again, and contact your cloud administrator if the problem persists.
{code}
If I hit the back button, I am able to get back into the GUI console.  I tried all of the following areas and received the same error:
* Launch Instance\Auto-scaling
* Allocate Elastic IP
* Create Launch Configuration
* Create Security Group
* Create Keypair
* Create Load Balancer
* Create Volume
* Create Snapshot

[~dkavanagh]: Here's the output from the eucaconsole.log I captured while trying to create a volume with ReadOnly permissions: {code} 2015-09-30 12:48:49 DEBUG Using access key provided by client.
